description: Perhaps from Latin dorsum (“the back”), i.e. what one lies on when sleeping; perhaps from English dialect doss (“a hassock”).

entries.meaning: (Scotland) Useless or lazy. Generally combined with expletive noun, especially cunt.
examples: Get a hauld o yersel, ya  doss cunt!
The place is pure doss, like.

entries.meaning: (slang, Britain and Ireland) The avoidance of work.
examples: I am going to have a doss tomorrow.

entries.meaning: (slang, Britain and Ireland) An easy piece of work.
examples: Circumnavigating the world in a canoe is no doss.

entries.meaning: (slang, dated, Britain and Ireland) A place to sleep in; a bed.
(slang, dated, Britain and Ireland, by extension) Sleep.

verbs.description: doss (third-person singular simple present dosses, present participle dossing, simple past and past participle dossed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Britain and Ireland) To avoid work, shirk, etc.
examples: I am going to doss tomorrow when the match is on.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Britain, slang) To sleep in the open or in a derelict building because one is homeless.
examples: I normally have to doss in shop doorways or park benches.
